pages:
Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 40576 
November 2006 
 
 
 
Islamic Republic of Pakistan: Establishment and 
Commencement of Operations for the Central Power 
Purchasing Agency 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 10 November 2006) 
 
Currency Unit –  Pakistan rupee/s (PRe/PRs) 
PRe1.00 =  $0.0165 
$1.00 =  PRs60.69 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CPPA  –  Central Power Purchasing Agency 
  NTDC  –  National Transmission Despatch Company 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  WAPDA  –  Water and Power Development Authority 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Energy 
Subsector  –  Energy sector development 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, capacity development, private sector 
development 
Subthemes  –  Fostering  physical  infrastructure  development,  public-private 
partnerships, institutional development 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice President  L. Jin, Operations Group 1 
Director General  J. Miranda, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  S. O’Sullivan, Infrastructure Division, CWRD 
   
Team leader  R. Stroem, Principal Energy Specialist, CWRD 
Team member  F. Kawawaki, Senior Investment Specialist (Infrastructure), CWRD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  Fact-Finding  Mission  for  the  proposed  Transmission  Enhancement 
Investment Program, the Government of Pakistan requested technical assistance (TA) from 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) to assist in establishing and commencing operations of the 
Central Power Purchasing Agency (CPPA). Approval from the Vice President on the concept 
paper  was  given  on  15  September  2006.  The  Fact-Finding  Mission  visited  Pakistan  in 
September 2006 to formulate the TA. The Government gave its concurrence with the impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference of the consultants. The TA framework appears in Appendix 1.1
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Pakistan’s  power  sector  is  experiencing  tremendous  challenges  in  supporting  the 
Government’s strategy to increase electricity supply to its urban and rural population. Nearly 
45% of the population does not have access to electricity. The power sector, a key infrastructure 
provider, will need to increase its capacity to sustain higher economic growth targets expressed 
in  the  Medium  Term  Development  Framework  2005–2010,  and  thereby  to  assist  in 
implementing the Government’s poverty reduction strategy. The key challenges are (i) lack of 
generation capacity, (ii) constraints in the transmission and distribution systems, (iii) financial 
management  and  sustainability  of  sector  entities,  and  (iv)  instituting  proper  corporate 
governance structures for the successor companies of the Water and Power Development 
Authority (WAPDA).2
 
3.  To  address  these  challenges,  the  Government  of  Pakistan  (the  Government)  has 
approved  power  sector  policies  and  strategies  and  it  has  instituted  action  plans.  The 
Government started the unbundling of the power sector in 1998. The National Transmission and 
Despatch Company (NTDC) was established the following year with a mandate to provide 
(i) transmission  of  electricity  through  the  220-kilovolt  and  500-kilovolt  network,  (ii)  system 
operation and dispatch functions for all power generation linked to the national grid, and (iii) the 
single purchase and seller functions of the power sector. To further realize the efficiencies and 
other benefits from restructuring and unbundling, the Government has decided to separate the 
last function from NTDC and create an autonomous body. This is in line with advice from ADB, 
which was further reinforced by the recommendations of ADB’s capacity building technical 
assistance for NTDC.3 The TA undertook an analysis of the single-buyer model and drafted the 
necessary agreements. The single buyer is defined as the purchaser of all wholesale electricity 
requirements from all available generators on behalf of the consumers and the seller under a 
bulk supply tariff to all consumers (distribution companies and large customers). Although the 
financial accounts have been integrated as part of NTDC’s accounts, the CPPA function until 
recently  was  administered  by  a  division  of  WAPDA,  which  is  WAPDA  Private  Power 
Organization. The division has been operational since the independent power producers started 
generating power in accordance with the 1994 power policy. A part of the division is now 
preparing to become an autonomous entity, CPPA.  
 
4.  According to Government plans, CPPA was scheduled to start its operations as an 
autonomous entity by the beginning of July 2006. The Government  has faced difficulty in 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 12 October 2006.  
2  Eight distribution companies, four generation companies, and the National Transmission Despatch Company were 
established from the divisions and departments of WAPDA. 
3  ADB. 2003 Technical Assistance to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for Institutional Capacity Building of National 
Transmission and Despatch Company Limited. Manila.

2   
achieving this goal because of the complex nature of the entity that would act as the center of 
demand and supply in the electricity market. The delay has added to uncertainty surrounding 
the future structure of the sector.  
 
5.  A long-term road map and action plan for the function to be taken on by CPPA is stated 
in NTDC’s license and Transitional Order No. 1 (i.e., phase 1: single buyer, phase 2: single 
buyer plus, phase 3: competitive wholesale market [competitive trading and bilateral contract 
market], and phase 4: retail competition). Before establishing CPPA, details are needed on the 
distribution of functions for power trading, organizational and financial structure of CPPA, and 
action plan to realize the long-term road map. The financial viability and credibility of CPPA is 
especially important for the private sector power producers, since CPPA is intended to be the 
counterpart to power purchase agreements.  
 
6.  The single-buyer function has contributed most of NTDC’s losses. The generation tariffs 
already have been adjusted to reach cost recovery but the consumer tariffs have lagged behind. 
This  gap  is  accumulated  in  NTDC  accounts  as  losses.  The  outstanding  receivables  from 
distribution  companies  have  also  burdened  NTDC’s  financial  accounts.  The  financial 
attractiveness of the independent CPPA to the commercial participants will be dependent upon 
(i) how the current financial position of the single-buyer function will be resolved, (ii) its future 
financial viability, and (iii) its creditworthiness.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact would be for improved efficiency in the power sector to lower the cost of 
electricity. The merit-order competition, further enhanced by CPPA, will foster the incentives and 
environment for power generators to actively seek cost efficiency in their operations and act to 
set benchmarks for the sector. The outcome is for a sustainable trading system in electricity to 
be established and operate. Establishing CPPA and its commencing operations will be the first 
steps toward the final goal of a multi-buyer and multi-seller trading system.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will have two phases. In the first phase, the consultants will build upon the work 
of the previous TA. Detailed diagnostics will be updated on the current situation and then the 
consultants will map out a recommended distribution of roles and institutional structures for the 
various functions involved in electricity trading and settlement (the roles of CPPA and of the 
dispatcher, NTDC, as well as of other related entities will be clearly defined). The consultants 
will do a stocktaking of the current state of readiness and produce the road map for CPPA’s 
establishment and operations as an autonomous entity.   
 
9.  The  second  phase  of  the  TA  will  focus  on  establishing  CPPA  and  starting  up  its 
operations.  This  phase  will  have  four  subcomponents:  (i)  documentation,  (ii)  training,  (iii) 
computer system, and (iv) settlement mechanism. Since there is a trading system in place, the 
various documents necessary for establishment will be in different stages of development. The 
consultants will start by analyzing the existing documents and procedures and suggest changes 
or redraft to enable CPPA to operate as an autonomous entity and to manage various forms of 
commercial sector participation in the power sector. Regarding establishment, the consultants 
will  assist  in  reviewing,  revising,  drafting,  and  finalizing,  as  required,  the  (i) necessary 
incorporation documents (including Articles of Association), (ii) business and financing plans, (iii)

3
corporate and management plan (including the code of conduct for staff and management), (iv) 
commercial  code  and  standard  agreements  with  the  market  participants  (including 
strengthening of agreements with distribution companies, generation companies, independent 
power producers, Karachi Electric Supply Corporation, and WAPDA Hydel), (v) organization and 
management structure, and (vi) trading standard procedures (i.e., demand and supply forecast, 
tariff application, procurement, risk management, and accounting). The consultants will give 
initial  training  to  (i)  staff  on  trading  standard  procedures,  (ii)  trainers  in  order  to  educate 
participating institutions (generation companies, distribution companies, and independent power 
producers) on dealing with CPPA, and (iii) staff with regard to educating the public.  
 
10.  Trading computer system requirements will be analyzed and a system development plan 
drafted that includes the principle software and hardware requirements for the first 5 years of 
operation. The detailed plan for the initial system will be based on analysis of the current system. 
The TA will support the financing of necessary software and hardware.  
 
11.  The  Contracts  Registrar  and  Power  Exchange  Administrator  is  the  market  and 
settlement operator envisaged by the Government, but it is not yet established. In the initial 
stage,  this  function  is  intended  to  be  included  in  CPPA.  The  TA  will  analyze  the  current 
settlement mechanism and recommend a system for this operation, including billing and cash 
transfer.  
 
12.  The financing plan will give special attention to addressing (i) a solution for existing 
receivables and payment issues, (ii) creditworthiness of CPPA, and (iii) cross-subsidy issues 
between distribution companies. The corporate and management plan will address such issues 
as  corporate  governance,  conflicts  of  interest,  and  fiduciary  responsibilities  of  staff  and 
management.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The estimated cost of the TA is $1,187,500 equivalent. The Government has asked ADB 
to  finance  $950,000  equivalent  on  a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  The 
Government will provide $237,500 equivalent to finance counterpart staff, office facilities, and 
other expenditures (Appendix 2). 
 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The Ministry of Water and Power will be the Executing Agency for the TA, while the 
CPPA (initially as a part of NTDC and later as an independent agency) will be the Implementing 
Agency.  The  TA  will  engage  international  consultants  for  20  person-months  and  national 
consultants for 20 person-months. The international consultants will have extensive experience 
in legal, trading, system, and settlement aspects of electricity trading. The national consultants 
will have expertise in the power sector, computer systems as well as in legal and regulatory 
matters. The first phase of the TA is expected to take 4 months and the second phase 12 
months. The outline terms of reference and reporting arrangements are in Appendix 3. Tripartite 
meetings involving CPPA and ADB will be held after submission of the inception, interim, and 
draft final reports. A consulting firm or consortium of firms will be selected and engaged in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for selecting and engaging national consultants. Recruitment of consultants 
will be done in accordance with quality- and cost-based selection procedures, and simplified 
technical proposals will be requested. The procurement of equipment under the TA will be

4   
conducted in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. The equipment and software will 
be procured through shopping or Limited International Bidding. The TA will begin in December 
2006 and be completed by April 2008.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $950,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Pakistan  for  the  Establishment  and  Commencement  of  Operations  for 
Central  Power  Purchasing  Agency,  and  hereby  reports  this  action  to  the  Board.

Appendix 1  5

8  Appendix 2

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

Appendix 3  9 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   Introduction 
 
1.  The scope of the Central Power Purchasing Agency (CPPA) is set out in the license for the 
National Transmission and Despatch Company (NTDC). The Government has determined that 
CPPA will become an entity autonomous from NTDC. The objective of this assistance is to support 
and enable the CPPA’s establishment and commencement of its operations.  
2.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  require  a  combination  of  international  and  national 
experts. The international consultants must have in-depth experience in power sector trading. The 
local experts must have substantial experience in the power sector, as well as with legal and 
regulatory issues. About 20 person-months (on an intermittent basis) of international consulting 
inputs are envisaged, and some 20 person-months of national consulting inputs will be needed. In 
order for the technical assistance to be effective, the consultants will be an integral part of the 
CPPA during its establishment and commencement of operations. 
 
B.  International Electricity Trade Expert (9 person-months) and National Power Expert (10 
person-months) 
 
3.  The international expert will act as the team leader and the national expert as the deputy 
team leader. The consultants’ outline terms of reference will include, but will not necessarily be 
limited to, the following tasks: 
 
  1.  Phase 1 
 
(i)  Build upon the work of the previous TA and perform detailed diagnostics on the 
current situation. 
(ii)  Map out a recommended distribution of roles and institutional structures for the 
various functions involved in electricity trading and settlement. The role of the CPPA, 
dispatcher (NTDC), and other related entities will be clearly defined. 
(iii)  Take  stock  of  the  current  state  of  readiness  and  produce  a  road  map  for  the 
establishment and operation of CPPA as an autonomous entity.  
(iv)  Produce a draft long-term road map for the transitional phase stated in the NTDC 
license and Transitional Order No. 1 (i.e., phase 1 single buyer, phase 2 single 
buyer plus, phase 3 competitive wholesale market [competitive trading and bilateral 
contract market], and phase 4 retail competition). 
(v)  Recommend  means  of  resolving  the  existing  receivables  and  payment  issues, 
establishing CPPA’s creditworthiness, and a methodology for cross-subsidy issues 
between distribution companies. 
 
  2.  Phase 2 
 
(i)  Assist in finalizing the incorporation documents. 
(ii)  Draft a management and organizational structure. 
(iii)  Assist in developing, reviewing, and revising drafts of the business and financing 
plans and assist in their finalization, as necessary. 
(iv)  Analyze existing documents and procedures.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
(v)  For the existing documents and procedures, suggest changes or redraft to enable 
CPPA in its new form as an autonomous entity and also to be able to manage 
different forms of commercial sector participation in the power sector. 
(vi)  Assist in revising and finalizing the commercial code and standard agreements with 
the  market  participants  (including  strengthening  of  agreements  with  distribution 
companies, generating companies, independent power producers, Karachi Electric 
Supply Corporation, and WAPDA Hydel).  
(vii)  Draft a corporate and management plan (including the code of conduct for staff and 
management). 
(viii)  Develop  trading  standard  procedures  (i.e.,  demand  and  supply  forecast,  tariff 
petition, procurement, risk management, accounting, metering code, bill collecting 
and invoicing, and subsidy mechanism).  
(ix)  Suggest  organizational  structure  and  operational  guidelines  for  checking  and 
monitoring reports, as well as for interface with the Finance Division.  
(x)  Give initial training to staff on trading standard procedures. 
(xi)  Train  trainers  to  educate  participating  institutions  (generation  and  distribution 
companies, independent power producers) on dealing with CPPA.  
(xii)  Train staff to educate the public.  
 
3.  Trading  System  Experts  (5  person-months  international  and  5  person-months 
national) 
 
4.  A computer system development plan will be drafted and include the principle, software and 
hardware requirements for the first 5 years of operation. The detailed plan will be made for the 
initial system based on analysis of the current system, and it will suggest software and hardware 
for that initial system. 
 
  4.  International Trading Settlement Expert (3 person-months) 
 
5.  The settlement expert will assist the trading expert in analyzing and formulating the map for 
distribution of roles, as well as in preparing the short-term and long-term plans. The consultant will 
analyze  the  current  settlement  mechanism  and  recommend  a  system  for  this  operation  that 
includes billing and cash transfer for the single-buyer and single-buyer plus models. He or she will 
develop systems specifications for the settlements system to conform with the trading standard 
procedures.  The  work  will  include  producing  a  plan  for  risk  mitigation  to  maintain  CPPA’s 
creditworthiness and integrity. The consultant will also draft guidelines for opening and maintaining 
escrow accounts for distribution companies and instructions for escrow accounts. In addition, he or 
she will provide methodology for six months of hand-holding for such accounts.  
 
  5.  Legal Consultants (3 person-months international, 5 person-months national) 
 
6.  The legal consultants will 
 
(i)  Review  and  draft  incorporation  documents,  including  the  memorandum  of 
association   
(ii)  Review power purchase agreements, advice as to the CPPA’s obligations, then 
reflect these obligations in the trading standard procedures. 
(iii)  Hold discussions with Private Power and Infrastructure Board and reflect possible 
future arrangements with the private sector in the trading standard procedures. 
(iv)  Review  and  revise  other  documents  as  necessary  from  a  legal  and  regulatory 
perspective.

Appendix 3  11 
 
 
C.   Reporting Requirements 
 
7.  The team leader will submit an inception report 4 weeks after fielding of the consultants. 
The draft inception report will be reviewed and discussed in a tripartite meeting 6 weeks after the 
fielding of the consultants. The draft interim report is due 6 months after commencement of the TA, 
and the draft final report is due 16 months after the commencement. Additional theme and system 
reports  will  be  prepared  as  required  and  identified  in  the  inception  report.  Training  session 
logbooks and material will be placed in several folders for reference by current and future CPPA 
management and staff.

development
